XGBoost Baseline API¶

Vectoriser Options¶

The slate baseline supports multiple text featurisation strategies via the --text_vectorizer CLI switch (and the matching fields on XGBoostTrainConfig):

  • tfidf – sparse TF-IDF features (default, no extra dependencies).

  • word2vec – averaged Word2Vec embeddings (requires gensim).

  • sentence_transformer – pooled Sentence-Transformer embeddings (requires the sentence-transformers package and a compatible PyTorch backend).

Use the accompanying CLI flags (--word2vec-* or --sentence-transformer-*) to tune embedding dimensionality, model checkpoints, batch sizes, and normalisation.

XGBoost-facing re-exports of the shared dataset helpers.

xgb.data.filter_dataset_for_issue(dataset, issue)[source]¶

Filter a dataset down to a specific issue label.

Parameters:

  • dataset (datasets.DatasetDict) – Dataset dictionary containing the issue column.

  • issue (str) – Issue label to retain (all preserves every row).

Returns:

Dataset dictionary restricted to rows matching issue.

Return type:

datasets.DatasetDict

Filter the dataset to rows whose participant_study matches studies.

Parameters:

  • dataset (datasets.DatasetDict) – Dataset dictionary containing the participant_study column.

  • studies (Iterable[str]) – Study identifiers to retain.

Returns:

Dataset dictionary filtered to the requested studies.

Return type:

datasets.DatasetDict

Filter a dataset split to the requested participant_study tokens.

Parameters:

  • studies (Sequence[str]) – Study identifiers to retain.

Returns:

Filtered dataset split covering only the requested studies.

Return type:

datasets.Dataset

Return the list of issue labels present in the dataset.

Parameters:

dataset (datasets.DatasetDict) – Dataset dictionary containing at least one split.

Returns:

Sorted list of issue identifiers or ['all'] when absent.

Return type:

List[str]

xgb.data.load_dataset_source(source, cache_dir)[source]¶

Load a cleaned dataset from disk or from the Hugging Face Hub.

Parameters:

  • source (str) – Local directory path or Hugging Face dataset identifier.

  • cache_dir (str) – Cache directory passed to datasets.load_dataset().

Returns:

Dataset dictionary containing train and validation splits.

Return type:

datasets.DatasetDict

Raises:

  • ImportError – If datasets is unavailable.

  • ValueError – When source does not yield a datasets.DatasetDict.

  • max_train (int) – Optional cap on the number of training examples.

  • workers (int) – Number of worker threads used during training.

  • seed (int) – Random seed for reproducibility.

  • model_dir (str | None) – Directory containing persisted Word2Vec artefacts.

xgb.model.fit_xgboost_model(train_ds, *, config=None, extra_fields=None, eval_ds=None, collect_history=False)[source]¶

Train an XGBoost multi-class classifier over prompt documents.

Parameters:

  • train_ds (datasets.Dataset or sequence-like) – Dataset split providing training examples.

  • config (XGBoostTrainConfig, optional) – Hyper-parameter bundle controlling training behaviour, including subsampling limits and booster hyper-parameters.

  • extra_fields (Sequence[str], optional) – Optional column names appended to the prompt document.

  • eval_ds (datasets.Dataset | Sequence[dict] | None) – Optional evaluation split monitored during fitting.

  • collect_history (bool) – When True record per-round training metrics.

Returns:

Trained model bundle containing vectoriser, label encoder, booster, and history.

Return type:

XGBoostSlateModel

Raises:

  • ImportError – If the upstream xgboost package is unavailable.

  • RuntimeError – When the training split is empty or lacks diverse labels.

Parameters:

in_dir (Path or str) – Directory containing the saved bundle.

Returns:

Restored model bundle.

Return type:

XGBoostSlateModel

Predict which slate option should be selected for example.

Parameters:

  • model (XGBoostSlateModel) – Trained model bundle used for inference.

  • example (dict) – Interaction row containing prompt text and candidate slate.

  • extra_fields (Sequence[str], optional) – Optional override of additional columns appended during inference.

Returns:

Tuple with a 1-based predicted option index (None when unknown) and per-video probabilities.

Return type:

Tuple[Optional[int], Dict[str, float]]

Persist a trained XGBoost model bundle to out_dir.

Core Config Internals¶

Configuration dataclasses for the XGBoost baseline.

This module groups booster and training configuration structures to keep model.py focused on the training pipeline logic and reduce file size. Where possible, constructors accept grouped configs and **kwargs for backward compatibility with older flat argument patterns.

class xgb.core.model_config.XGBoostBoosterParams(*, extra_kwargs=None, core=None, sampling=None, regularization=None, **flat_kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

XGBoost hyper-parameters grouped into sub-configs.

Backwards-compatible usage via flat keyword arguments is supported using **kwargs. Prefer constructing grouped sub-configs for clarity.

  • regularization (_BoosterRegularization | None)

Bases: object

Configuration options controlling training behaviour.

Variables:

  • max_train (int) – Maximum number of rows sampled from the training split (0 keeps all).

  • max_features (int | None) – Maximum number of TF-IDF features (None for unlimited).

  • vectorizer_kind (str) – Feature extraction strategy (tfidf, word2vec, or sentence_transformer).

  • booster (XGBoostBoosterParams) – Hyper-parameter bundle applied when initialising the booster.

Parameters:

class xgb.evaluate.IssueMetrics(issue, participant_studies, dataset_source, evaluated, correct, accuracy, known_candidate_hits, known_candidate_total, coverage, avg_probability, eligible, timestamp, extra_fields, xgboost_params, correct_eligible=0, accuracy_eligible=0.0, known_accuracy=None, known_availability=None, evaluated_predicted=0, accuracy_predicted=0.0, baseline_most_frequent_gold_index=<factory>, random_baseline_expected_accuracy=None, curve_metrics=None, curve_metrics_path=None, accuracy_ci_95=None, accuracy_uncertainty=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Container describing evaluation metrics for a single issue.

Variables:

  • issue – Human-readable issue label.

  • participant_studies – Participant study filters applied to evaluation rows.

  • dataset_source – Identifier of the dataset (path or Hub id).

  • evaluated – Number of evaluation rows processed.

  • correct – Count of correct slate selections.

  • accuracy – Overall accuracy across all evaluated rows.

  • known_candidate_hits – Correct selections where the candidate was seen during training.

  • known_candidate_total – Evaluations containing at least one known candidate.

  • coverage – Fraction of evaluations with at least one known candidate.

  • avg_probability – Mean probability assigned to known predictions.

  • eligible – Count of slates containing the gold option.

  • timestamp – UNIX timestamp when the metrics were produced.

  • extra_fields – Extra prompt fields incorporated during evaluation.

  • xgboost_params – Serialised model parameter summary.

  • correct_eligible – Correct selections restricted to eligible slates.

  • accuracy_eligible – Accuracy among eligible slates.

  • known_accuracy – Accuracy on rows with known candidates.

  • known_availability – Ratio of rows with known candidates to those evaluated.

  • evaluated_predicted – Evaluations where the model emitted a prediction.

  • accuracy_predicted – Accuracy among rows with predictions.

  • baseline_most_frequent_gold_index – Baseline statistics for the most frequent gold index.

  • random_baseline_expected_accuracy – Expected accuracy of a random chooser baseline.

  • curve_metrics – Learning-curve payload summarising cumulative accuracy trends.

  • curve_metrics_path – Optional filesystem path where curve metrics were persisted.

  • accuracy_ci_95 – Bootstrap 95% confidence interval for eligible-only accuracy.

  • accuracy_uncertainty – Full bootstrap payload including model/baseline statistics.

Parameters:

  • issue (str)

class xgb.evaluate.PredictionOutcome(prediction_index, predicted_id, gold_video_id, candidate_probs, best_probability, known_candidate_seen, known_candidate_hit, record_probability, correct, option_count, gold_index, eligible)[source]¶

Bases: object

Result bundle for a single evaluation example.

Variables:

  • prediction_index – 1-based predicted option index (None when abstaining).

  • predicted_id – Video identifier returned by the model.

  • gold_video_id – Ground-truth video identifier.

  • candidate_probs – Mapping of slate indices to predicted probabilities.

  • best_probability – Probability associated with the predicted option.

  • known_candidate_seen – Flag indicating at least one known candidate was present.

  • known_candidate_hit – Flag indicating the prediction matched a known candidate.

  • record_probability – Flag controlling whether the probability contributes to aggregates.

  • correct – True when the predicted candidate matches the gold id.

  • option_count – Number of slate options presented to the model.

  • gold_index – 1-based index of the gold candidate (when present).

  • eligible – True when the slate contained the gold candidate.

Parameters:

  • prediction_index (int | None)

  • predicted_id (str)

  • gold_video_id (str)

Return type:

logging.Logger

Pipeline Orchestration¶

The orchestration layer exposes dedicated stages for the slate-ranking and opinion-regression tasks. Pass --tasks to python -m xgb.pipeline (or the training wrapper scripts) to select which portions to run:

  • next_video – plan and execute hyper-parameter sweeps for the slate model, promote the best configurations, and run the final validation pass.

  • opinion – run the opinion-regression sweeps independently, select the best booster parameters, and train the regression models used in downstream reporting.

When a task is disabled the generated Markdown reports now include a short note explaining that the section was intentionally skipped.

Pipeline orchestration for the XGBoost baselines.

This package coordinates sweep execution, evaluation, and report emission for the slate-ranking and opinion-regression XGBoost workflows. The heavy lifting now lives in submodules (settings, stages, runner) to keep this module lightweight and focused on the public surface.

xgb.pipeline.main(argv=None)[source]¶

Entry point orchestrating the full XGBoost workflow.

Parameters:

argv (Sequence[str] | None)

Return type:

None

Command-line helpers for the Grail Simulation XGBoost pipeline.

Provides argument parsing, default-directory resolution, and sweep grid builders consumed by xgb.pipeline and its orchestration helpers.

Data structures describing the Grail Simulation XGBoost pipeline.

Defines sweep configuration objects, execution contexts, and selection results exchanged between the sweep, evaluation, and reporting stages.

This package splits the original monolithic module into focused submodules while preserving the public API at xgb.pipeline.context.

__init__(*, sweep_dir, data=None, vectorizers=None, xgb=None, **legacy_kwargs)[source]

Construct a grouped run context, also accepting legacy flat kwargs.

Preferred usage passes grouped settings via data, vectorizers, and xgb. For backwards compatibility, legacy keyword arguments are also accepted through **legacy_kwargs. Supported legacy keys are: dataset, cache_dir, extra_fields, max_participants, seed, max_features, tree_method, overwrite, tfidf_config, word2vec_config, sentence_transformer_config, and word2vec_model_base.

Parameters:

  • sweep_dir (Path) – Root directory where sweep artefacts are written.

  • data (OpinionDataSettings, optional) – Pre-grouped dataset and sampling settings.

  • vectorizers (OpinionVectorizerSettings, optional) – Pre-grouped vectoriser configurations.

  • xgb (OpinionXgbSettings, optional) – Pre-grouped XGBoost shared settings for sweeps.

  • legacy_kwargs (Mapping[str, object]) – Legacy flat kwargs listed above.

Returns:

None.

class xgb.pipeline_context.SweepConfig(text_vectorizer, vectorizer_tag, booster=None, *, learning_rate=None, max_depth=None, n_estimators=None, subsample=None, colsample_bytree=None, reg_lambda=None, reg_alpha=None, vectorizer_cli=())

Bases: object

Hyper-parameter configuration evaluated during XGBoost sweeps.

Parameters:

  • text_vectorizer (str) – Vectoriser identifier (e.g. tfidf).

  • vectorizer_tag (str) – Short tag used in directory and report labels.

  • learning_rate (float) – Booster learning rate.

  • max_depth (int) – Tree depth explored during sweeps.

  • n_estimators (int) – Number of boosting rounds.

  • subsample (float) – Row subsampling ratio.

  • colsample_bytree (float) – Column subsampling ratio per tree.

  • reg_lambda (float) – L2 regularisation weight.

  • reg_alpha (float) – L1 regularisation weight.

  • vectorizer_cli (Tuple[str, ...]) – Extra CLI arguments associated with the vectoriser.

  • booster (BoosterParams | None)

booster: BoosterParams

class xgb.pipeline_context.SweepOutcome(*, order_index, study, config, metrics_path=None, metrics=None, accuracy=None, coverage=None, evaluated=None)

Bases: common.pipeline.types.BasePipelineSweepOutcome[xgb.pipeline.context.SweepConfig]

Metrics captured for a (study, configuration) sweep evaluation.

The measured fields are exposed as properties backed by the raw metrics mapping to keep the instance attribute count small.

Parameters:

  • order_index (int)

  • config (xgb.pipeline.context.SweepConfig)

  • metrics_path (Path | None)

  • metrics (dict | None)

  • accuracy (float | None)

  • coverage (float | None)

  • evaluated (int | None)

property accuracy: float

Accuracy measured on eligible rows when available.

Falls back to overall accuracy if eligible-only metric is absent. Returns 0.0 if the metric cannot be parsed as a float.

property coverage: float

Coverage (fraction of evaluated rows) as a float.

Returns 0.0 if the metric is missing or invalid.

property evaluated: int

Support size, i.e. number of evaluated rows.

Returns 0 if the metric is missing or invalid.

as_dict()[source]

Summarise task metadata for logging or diagnostics.

Provides a lightweight, serialisable view exposing the core fields needed to understand what will be executed.

Return type:

dict[str, object]

property tree_method: str

XGBoost tree construction algorithm used for this task.

Data structures describing the Grail Simulation XGBoost pipeline.

Defines sweep configuration objects, execution contexts, and selection results exchanged between the sweep, evaluation, and reporting stages.

This package splits the original monolithic module into focused submodules while preserving the public API at xgb.pipeline.context.

__init__(*, sweep_dir, data=None, vectorizers=None, xgb=None, **legacy_kwargs)[source]¶

Construct a grouped run context, also accepting legacy flat kwargs.

Preferred usage passes grouped settings via data, vectorizers, and xgb. For backwards compatibility, legacy keyword arguments are also accepted through **legacy_kwargs. Supported legacy keys are: dataset, cache_dir, extra_fields, max_participants, seed, max_features, tree_method, overwrite, tfidf_config, word2vec_config, sentence_transformer_config, and word2vec_model_base.

Parameters:

  • sweep_dir (Path) – Root directory where sweep artefacts are written.

  • data (OpinionDataSettings, optional) – Pre-grouped dataset and sampling settings.

  • vectorizers (OpinionVectorizerSettings, optional) – Pre-grouped vectoriser configurations.

  • xgb (OpinionXgbSettings, optional) – Pre-grouped XGBoost shared settings for sweeps.

  • legacy_kwargs (Mapping[str, object]) – Legacy flat kwargs listed above.

Returns:

None.

Return type:

None

  • index (int)

  • config (xgb.pipeline.context.SweepConfig)

  • base_cli (Tuple[str, ...])

  • extra_cli (Tuple[str, ...])

  • run_root (Path)

  • tree_method (str)

  • metrics_path (Path)

  • train_participant_studies (Tuple[str, ...])

as_dict()[source]¶

Summarise task metadata for logging or diagnostics.

Provides a lightweight, serialisable view exposing the core fields needed to understand what will be executed.

Return type:

dict[str, object]

property tree_method: str¶

XGBoost tree construction algorithm used for this task.

Opinion summary structures with legacy attribute compatibility.

The OpinionSummary dataclass groups related metrics into logical sub-structures and implements compatibility access for legacy flat field names via a small forwarding map. A convenience constructor builds an instance from keyword arguments using those flat names.

label: str | None = None¶
participants: int | None = None¶
split: str | None = None¶

Evaluation runners for the Grail Simulation XGBoost pipeline.

Wraps the CLI entry points that execute the selected sweeps, perform cross-study checks, and run opinion regressions while honouring reuse settings configured by xgb.pipeline.

Compatibility layer exposing the legacy xgb.pipeline_reports API.

The production modules now live under xgb.pipeline.reports. Tests and downstream scripts still rely on the legacy import paths, so we re-export the public entry points here to ease the transition to the reorganised package.

Sweep orchestration helpers for the Grail Simulation XGBoost pipeline.

xgb.pipeline_sweeps.execute_opinion_sweep_tasks(tasks, *, jobs)¶

Execute opinion sweep tasks, optionally in parallel.

Parameters:

  • tasks (Sequence[OpinionSweepTask]) – Opinion sweep tasks scheduled for execution.

  • jobs (int) – Maximum number of concurrent worker processes.

Returns:

Opinion sweep outcomes computed for each task.

Return type:

List[OpinionSweepOutcome]

xgb.pipeline_sweeps.prepare_opinion_sweep_tasks(*, studies, configs, context, reuse_existing)[source]¶

Public wrapper around the private _prepare_opinion_sweep_tasks.

See prepare_sweep_tasks() for rationale.

xgb.pipeline_sweeps.prepare_sweep_tasks(*, studies, configs, context, reuse_existing)[source]¶

Public wrapper around the private _prepare_sweep_tasks.

This preserves the original behaviour while allowing upstream code to call a public API (avoiding Pylint’s protected-member warning).
